THRO, THRO General
69.1 THRO General
� General Information
Modern engines are equipped with a drive by wire system. The air mass ?ow is here controlled with an
electronic throttle actuator. The task of THRO is to adjust the requested throttle ?ap position dependent on
the engine operating states and the driver request. For this purpose the aggregate includes all necessary
functions for the closed-loop ETC position control and the corresponding level 1 diagnosis functions.
Additionally all level 1 diagnosis functions are observed from the limp-home management of the aggregate.
In case of safety critical errors occurs, the management is able to activate system fault reactions. Possible
fault reactions are the deactivation of the power stage, the reduction of the requested engine torque or the
limitation of the current engine speed.
� Architecture Overview
The following picture shows the function architecture of THRO. The software interface to the basic software for
the control of the generic ETC power stage (called H-bridge) is described in the module THRO ? requirements
for infrastructure interface.

THRO, THRO General
This module describes the interface between the application and basic software. It is used for the acquisition
of the measuring values delivered from the throttle measuring system, the right operation of the generic ETC
power stage and describes the calculation order during the closed-loop digital position control.
? ETC throttle angle variables
The throttle position measuring system delivers two linear sensor signal voltages for the calculation of the
throttle position. The described module is used for the acquisition and determination of the current throttle
position. The selection of the used position sensor for the digital position control depends on the state of the
corresponding diagnostic functions.
? ETC setpoint selection
The setpoint selection is used for the coordination of all possible throttle position setpoints requested from the
remaining software system. The selection depends on the current engine operating state. Finally the selected
setpoint is limited to a de?ned range to protect the throttle ?ap against mechanical damaging.
? ETC position controller
This module includes the digital position controller used for the closed-loop digital position control with an ETC
actuator according to the function principle DC motor and gear, currently torque motors are not supported.
Additionally the module (application incidence) manages all deactivation requests and is able to release the
ETC power stage via disable/enable line.
? ETC setpoint calculation at start
The setpoint calculation at start is a extension of the module ETC setpoint selection and provides the throttle
position setpoint during the engine start.
? ETC position sensor diagnosis
The position sensor diagnosis checks the physical voltage range of the throttle measuring system. Lies the
voltage values outside of the plausible range the diagnostic function will indicate an error and the error loca-
tion.
? ETC actuator diagnosis
The described function monitors the right functionality of the throttle actuator. In normal operating the throttle
?ap must be able to reach the requested setpoint position, otherwise an error will be indicated. The actuator
diagnosis observes the control deviation of the closed-loop position control system.
? ETC power stage diagnosis based on SPI
This module describes the diagnosis of the generic ETC power stage con?gured in SPI mode. The power stage
is intelligent electrical circuit with integrated diagnostic function. The diagnostic result is indicated on the SPI
line of the power stage. The purpose of the function is to evaluate the SPI line.
? ETC sensor plausibility check
The diagnosis function is used for the check of the homokinetic tolerance between both position sensors of
the throttle measuring system and for the plausibility check between air mass ?ow and throttle position sensor.

THRO, THRO General
The plausibility check with the air mass ?ow sensor will be performed only with an indicated error of the sensor
range check or a violation of the homokinetic tolerance.
? ETC actuator adaptation diagnosis
This functionality is split into the TPS start check and adaptation function with integrated diagnostic function.
The start check function is used for the check of the limp-home position and the test of the upper return spring
of the throttle actuator.
The TPS adaptation function is used for the adaptation of the throttle actuator. The lower mechanical stop,
the limp-home position and the ampli?cation of the measuring ampli?er will be adapted and saved in the
no-volatile memory. Additionally the function of the lower and upper return spring will be check during the
adaptation process.
? ETC limp-home management
The ETC limp-home management observes all level 1 diagnostic functions of THRO. In case of safety-critical
errors in the ETC system occurs fault reactions will be started. The function is able to deactivate the ETC power
stage, to reduce the engine torque and to limit the engine speed, if requested.

� General Information
Management of the throttle component. The aggregate receives a setpoint from ?Intake system?, coordinates
this with internal requests (throttle adaptation, limp home, ...) and realizes the setpoint with the position
controller. It determines the actual throttle position (including sensor adaptation) and performs all diagnosis
that can be done on component level.

� General Information
The throttle actuator is equipped with a twochannel linear sensor system. The propose of this module is
to determine the actual throttle position for closedloop throttle position control. The position sensors have
different signal properties, TPS 1 has a linear increase and TPS 2 a linear decrease characteristic ( standard
according to VDA working group ). An additional feature of this module is the support of an analog measuring
ampli?er for the throttle position sensor 1. It is possible to measured the throttle ?ap position with a high
resolution during engine idle speed. Therefore the function must standardise the throttle ?ap position under
consideration of the adaptation values, the different signal slopes ( normal or ampli?ed TPS channel ) and the
position sensor signal selection dependent on TPS diagnosis result.

Recurrence: 1MS, 10MS, SEG

69.4.2.1 Throttle position sensor signal ?ltering
The described ?lter function is a part of the signal processing. The AD values of the throttle position sensors
have a resolution of 10 bit (1024 increments) according to the AD converter. The smallest signi?cation bit, one
increment, is the fault of the AD conversion process and this bit can alternate from conversion to conversion.
To compensate this fault a bit ?lter is used, see below. Concerning system requirements (normal and ampli?ed
channel for TPS 1) the bit ?lters of TPS 1 and 2 are different.

69.4.2.2 Calculate throttle ?ap position
The propose of this chapter is to provide the throttle ?ap position for the ETC digital position controller. After
the determination of the processed signal voltages ( bit ?lter, over-sampling ) the throttle ?ap position is stan-
dardised by the signal slope of the sensor system dependent on the standard and the ampli?ed TPS channels
and the corresponding adaptation values. Furthermore the valid TPS channel for electronic throttle control is
chosen by the TPS diagnosis result at the end of the module.. This also switches the ETC_TPS to TPS_2 when
the TPS_1 Saturates.

69.4.2.2.3 Selection of the throttle control value TPS_ETC
This module describes the throttle position sensor signal selection in error-free and error case. The error
information is provided by the state variable STATE_TPS_DIAG delivered from the ETC limp-home management
and dependent on the state of the TPS diagnosis. Generally TPS 1 is used for ETC digital position control in an
error-free system..When TPS 1 is saturated TPS 2 is used in an error-free system.

69.4.2.2.4 Calculation of TPS_INSY
The throttle ?ap position TPS_INSY is needed as input for the intake manifold model.
The current throttle ?ap position TPS_ETC calculated time synchronous is copied in TPS_INSY
at every 2ms, in case of TPS double error, TPS_SEG is set to TPS_LIH_INI.

69.4.3 Throttle position auxiliary values
For the remaining system a high and low resolution throttle ?ap position are provided. The throttle ?ap position
TPS_ETC is written into a buffer of 5 values and in a time base of 10 ms the mean value TPS_AV is calculated.
TPS is a derivative from TPS_AV with low resolution.
The gradient of the throttle ?ap is calculated from the difference between actual throttle ?ap position and the
throttle ?ap position 40 ms before. The gradient is indicated as absolute value and the direction as logical
variable.

� General Information
This diagnosis function is used to monitor the admissible input voltage range of the throttle position sensor
system. The diagnostic is able to detect short circuit to battery, open circuit and short circuit to ground for
each position sensor input according to the pull resistor at the input of the AD converter.
Error-symptoms are de?ned to this function as following:
LV_SYM_VP_TPS_1_H - Short circuit to battery
LV_SYM_VP_TPS_1_L - Short circuit to ground or open load
LV_SYM_VP_TPS_2_H - Short circuit to battery
LV_SYM_VP_TPS_2_L - Short circuit to ground or open load
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

The ?ag LV_INH_DIAG_TPS permit to deactivate the corresponding diagnostics. As projects have different

Otherwise the information bit has to be set to LV_ERR_TPS_VCC respectively.

� General Information
This diagnosis function is used to monitor the power stage of the ETC.
The diagnostic is con?gurated in SPI mode and is able to detect short circuit (to power or ground), open circuit
and over heat.
Error symptoms are de?ned to this function as following:
Short circuit
Open circuit
Over heat protection

69.7.2.1.1.3 Short circuit diagnosis
A short circuit could only be detected at the switches from the H-bridge which are open.
So the condition for the different short cuts has to be calculated depending on the current PWM.
The different short cut symptoms are resumed after ?ltering each symptom.

69.9.3.1 Monitoring of the control deviation
This chapter describes the monitoring of the control deviation TPS_DIF from the position control system. The
control deviation may not be exceeded a de?ned value. This admissible threshold is calculated with a char-
acteristic line dependent on the gradient of the throttle position setpoint. The corresponding gradient is de-
termined by a low pass ?lter. The increment and decrement value of the implemented anti-bounce algorithm
can be calibrated.
Error-symptoms are de?ned to this diagnosis function as following :
LV_SYM_TPS_DIF - System deviation outside the valid range

69.9.3.1.4.1.2.1 Error record of control deviation symptom
69.9.3.2 Monitoring of the position controller output
This function is used to monitor the position controller output. When the PWM signal leaves the valid range
then an anti-bounce counter is started. If the anti-bounce counter exceeds a ?rst threshold then reversible
engine speed limitation should be requested but if the counter exceeds the second threshold then irreversible
engine speed limitation has to be requested. The increment and decrement value of the anti-bounce algorithm
can be calibrated.
Error-symptoms are de?ned to this diagnosis function as following :
LV_SYM_ETC_PWM_1 - PWM signal outside range step 1
LV_SYM_ETC_PWM_2 - PWM signal outside range step 2

� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
� General information:
The throttle position is determined by a two-channeled sensor. Both channels deliver inverse dispersing volt-
age signals. In order to reduce the measurement inaccuracy, the two signal voltages will be referenced to their
supply voltage. After the initial engine start and component change the sensor characteristic is learnt within
an adaptation routine. The learned values for the limp-home position, the lower mechanical stop and the TPS
1 ampli?cation are stored at the end of the driving cycle as "non-volatile".

69.11.4 Co-ordination of the adaptation functions
� Description:
The adaptation of the throttle position includes two sections: the start routine and adaptation routine. The
start routine is a part of the adaptation routine with owns thresholds and is carry out at every switch-on of the
engine control unit. The adaptation routine starts only if the adaptation is requested.
The actual adaptation condition LV_TPS_AD_ACT and the adaptation request LV_TPS_AD_REQ are de?ned in
the corresponding application incidence.
To get a plausible battery voltage the check of adaptation or start check is delayed T_DLY_TPS_AD after control
unit is switched on.

69.11.5 TPS start check and diagnosis
� Description:
The Start routine is carried out with every switch-on of the engine control unit (LV_IGK = 1). The TPS-adaptation
bit is active initialised (LV_TPS_AD_ACT =1) for the start-check or adaptation-routine. The routine includes the
following:
? Limp-home position check
? Adaptation of the limp-home position
? Upper return spring check
The start check is only carried out when the adaptation conditions are maintained otherwise it will be ignored
without error entry.
2 3
Time 
TOL 
LIH 
TPS 1
Tolerance bands for 
start check diagnosis 
Start check steps 
set point 
actual value 
4
The state variable TPS_AD_STEP indicates the following start check steps:
Adap. area TPS_AD_STEP Note 
1 ST_CHK_LIH Check and adaptation of the limp-home position 
2 ST_GO_TOL throttle flap goes into a upper positio n 
3 ST_SPR_CHK Upper return spring and limp-home chec k 
4 ST_CHK_END End of start check 
 
� Formula section:
start_check( )
switch( TPS_AD_STEP )
case ST_CHK_LIH: call function st_chk_lih( )
break

69.11.6 TPS adaptation and diagnosis
� Description:
Due to the electrical and the mechanical tolerances of the throttle position system, the sensor characteristic
has to be learnt. The adaptation and diagnosis of the lower mechanical stop and limp-home position occurs
within the adaptation routines. The adapted lower mechanical stop and the upper check position are used for
the calculation of the ampli?cation of the ampli?ed TPS 1 channel. The upper mechanical stop is not learned.
During the TPS adaptation no limitation of the throttle position setpoint is active. The learned value for the
limp-home position, the lower mechanical stop and the TPS 1 ampli?cation are stored at the end of the driving
cycle as "non-volatile".
The TPS adaptation includes the following functions:
? Adaptation and check of the limp-home position
? Adaptation and check of the lower mechanical stop
? Lower return spring check
? Adaptation of the ampli?er ampli?cation ( TPS 1 channel )
? Upper return spring check

69.11.6.1 Function ad_lih_pos(), adaptation of the limp-home position
� Description:
The ?rst step is the adaptation of the limp-home position. The actuator is without current and is forced by the
spring power in the limp home position.
During the adaptation all the voltage values must be in the adaptation windows. A hysteresis band is set up
around each of the ?rst recorded values ( TPS 1 and 2 ). If all the values lie in this hysteresis band during an
adjustable time then the adaptation values are determined from each ?rst and last value. If the TPS - value lies
outside the hysteresis band then the process is newly started for both TPS. The learning algorithm is limited
by the maximum time. This procedure is the same for the Limp home position and the lower mechanical stop.
Just the calibration values are different. An error is detected if the adaptation could not be carried out during
the maximum time C_T_MAX_TPS_AD.

� General Information
The adaptation demand is checked every time the control unit is switched on. The throttle position sensor
adaptation is necessary in the following cases:
? In initial start ( ?rst engine run or control unit exchange ), that means no adaptation values are stored in
the non-volatile memory
? After a component exchange, when the limp home position of the throttle ?ap is outside the diagnostic
window ( LV_TPS_AD_REQ_ST_CHK will be set )
? Check sum error ( NVMY ? error ) is current
? Initiated by the tester ( LV_TPS_AD_ACT_EXT_ADJ is set)
? Adaptation request bit LV_TPS_AD_REQ is set
Each of these points ends with a new adaptation request.
An additional TPS adaptation could be enabled by LC_TPS_AD_REQ_DLY. This TPS adaptation runs a de?ned
time (T_TPS_AD_DLY) after ignition on and is requested by LV_TPS_AD_REQ_DLY.
� Application Conditions

Activation: LV_FID_READY
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 5MS

� General Information
The diagnosis function is divided into the ?rst and second TPS error detection. In the ?rst error detection the
deviation between both position sensor signals is monitored and must not exceed a de?ned threshold.
In the second error detection one position sensor is already indicated as defective and the right function of
the other position sensor is checked continuously with the main load sensor.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON, DCON
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

69.13.2.1 TPS ratio check between TPS 1 and 2
The TPS ratio check monitors the admissible difference between throttle position sensor 1 and 2 (part of the
TPS ?rst error detection). The admissible difference C_TPS_RATIO_HYS mustn?t be exceeded for an adapted
throttle ?ap otherwise the algorithm will be detected an error in the measuring system.

69.13.2.2 Coordination of the TPS error information
The following chapter shall coordinate the plausibility check for the TPS system in case of TPS second error
detection is requested (one TPS error is already detected). The module is calculated after the TPS diagnoses
and monitors all possible TPS errors. In case of TPS errors the state variable STATE_TPS_DIAG indicates the
following error states for necessary fault reactions:
STATE_TPS_DIAG Note Fault reaction
TPS_NO_ERROR no faults in sensor system sensor 1 or mean value is active, no fault reaction
TPS_1_ERROR sensor 1 is faulty sensor 2 is active, torque reduction
TPS_2_ERROR sensor 2 is faulty sensor 1 is active, torque reduction
TPS_RATIO_ERR compare error sensor 1 is active, no fault reaction
TPS_DBL_ERROR both sensors are faulty limp-home request, ETC current-less

THRO, Electronic throttle control sensor plausibility check
Error symptoms are de?ned for this diagnosis function as:
LV_SYM_TPS_MAF_X - TPS X and MAF are not plausible
First error detection
The function is used for the TPS ?rst error detection. All possible TPS errors are monitored.
Error detection during TPS ratio error
The following function is only used when a TPS ratio error has been detected. The function shall set the con-
cerning plausibility symptoms LV_SYM_TPS_MAF_X. The requested plausibility information between throttle
position measuring system and mass air ?ow through the throttle ?ap must be provide by the corresponding
application incidence module.
End of diagnosis calculation
This function calculates the end of diagnosis conditions for the plausibility errors when TPS errors have not
been detected. In the error free TPS system the end of diagnosis conditions can be set if the end of diagnosis
information of the electrical diagnoses are available (without a corresponding error entry).
Second error detection, check TPS 1
The function is used for the TPS second error detection and shall check the remaining TPS 1 with the plausibility
result of the TPS MAF plausibility check. In case of further errors the TPS system is indicated as defective.
Second error detection, check TPS 2
The function is used for the TPS second error detection and shall check the remaining TPS 2 with the plausibil-
ity result of the TPS MAF plausibility check. In case of further errors the TPS system is indicated as defective.

Figure 69.14.2:
69.14.2 Overview OPM 10MS
General information:
The following section is used to check the plausibility between air mass ?ow through the throttle ?ap and the
corresponding throttle ?ap position delivered from the TPS signal acquisition. The diagnosis function is divided
into the ?rst and second error detection. In the ?rst error detection the deviation between both position sensor
signals is monitored and must not exceed a de?ned threshold.
In the second error detection one position sensor is indicated as defective and the right function of the other
position sensor is checked continuously with the main load sensor.
Description:
Detection of the implausible channel in the case of a comparison error within the admissible voltage ranges.
To perform this plausibility check, the variables MAF_TPS_SUB_X are calculated on the basis of the throttle
position values TPS_AV_X .
The absolute amount of the differences between MAF_TPS_SUB_X and the mass air ?ow measured are de-
termined, normalised with IP_MAF_TPS_DIF_DIAG and integrated over the period C_T_TPS_MAF_ERR_INT. After
the integration period the TPS channel which has the highest error sum is declared as faulty. The other chan-
nel is also declared as faulty, if it s error sum exceeds the threshold C_TPS_MAF_ERR_INT. If both error sums are
identical (threshold not exceeded ), TPS channel 1 is declared as faulty.

69.14.2.4 Diagnosis of ?rst TPS Error
The substitute values MAF_TPS_SUB_X are used for the plausibility check while the engine is running. The
differences between the measured mass air ?ow and the substitute values are normalised and integrated over
a period C_T_TPS_MAF_ERR_INT.
The plausibility check cannot be performed when a mass air ?ow signal is missing, in this case, the channels
are declared as faulty.

� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
The ETC limp-home management manages the fault reactions of the closed-loop throttle position control sys-
tem that would be engine torque/power limitation, engine speed limitation and ETC power stage deactivation.
Fault reactions will be requested when errors in the ETC system are indicated. The limp-home management
observes all ETC diagnosis functions and starts necessary fault reactions when any ETC errors are detected.
At the end of the module the logical variable LV_ERR_TPS is calculated for ETC system 1 and 2. The variable is
used to indicate debounced errors in the corresponding ETC system.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON, CLRFMY
Activation: always
Deactivation: never

69.15.2.1 Engine torque and power limitation
The variable STATE_TPS_DIAG contains all possible TPS errors and indicates the state of the throttle measuring
system. The state variable makes possible to request engine torque or power limitation in case of TPS error
are detected. The module is calculated after the TPS diagnoses to reduce time delays between error entry and
fault reaction request.
STATE_TPS_DIAG Note Fault reaction
TPS_NO_ERROR no faults in sensor system mean value from sensor 1 and sensor 2
TPS_1_ERROR sensor 1 is faulty sensor 2 is active, torque reduction
TPS_2_ERROR sensor 2 is faulty sensor 1 is active, torque reduction
TPS_RATIO_ERR compare error maximum of both sensors or mean value
TPS_DBL_ERROR both sensors are faulty limp-home request, ETC current-less

69.15.2.2 Global error bit of the ETC system

69.15.2.3 Engine speed limitation request
The ETC limp-home management monitors the correct function of the throttle position control system. If
safety critical errors are detected then engine speed limitation will be requested. Two variants of engine speed
limitation are available. The ?rst variant works with a constant engine speed limitation threshold and the
second variant has a variable threshold dependent on the driver request. The variable STATE_N_LIM_ETC_REQ
indicates all requests:
Mode STATE_N_LIM_ETC_REQ Note
0 N_NOT_LIM engine speed limitation isn?t requested
1 N_CON_LIM_1 a constant engine speed limitation is requested during brake active
2 N_CON_LIM_2 a constant engine speed limitation is requested
3 N_LIM_PVS_1 a variable engine speed limitation is requested,
the limitation speed is a function of PVS with fuel cut off
4 N_LIM_PVS_2 a variable engine speed limitation is requested,
the limitation speed is a function of PVS
The deactivation of the power stages has to be performed via enable/disable line between power stage and
main controller. Additionally the setpoint for the throttle ?ap limp-home position can be requested for the
position control system (power stage is activated) that means the limp-home position of the throttle ?ap is
adjusted by the position controller

TPS setpoint at start
� General Information
During start a separate TPS setpoint at start is calculated. There are two basic maps (dependent on N and
TCO) for manual and automatic transmission, which deliver the percentage of the opening of the throttle.
This basic value is corrected by an offset dependent on the pedal value and factors dependent on intake air
temperature TIA and ambient pressure AMP. The applied TPS setpoint is determined by a map dependent
on the percentage and the engine speed N. This map can be used to correct the non linear behavior of the
throttle (reduced area) or the behavior of the complete intake manifold.

This basic value is corrected by an offset dependent on the pedal value and factors dependent on intake air
temperature TIA and ambient pressure AMP. The applied TPS setpoint is determined by a map dependent
on the percentage and the engine speed N. This map can be used to correct the non linear behavior of the
throttle (reduced area) or the behavior of the complete intake manifold.

� General Information
In case of very low temperatures it is possible that the throttle actuator is jammed by ice. The described
module is used for the detection and the removing of ice between throttle ?ap and body. The functionality
is able to detect the location of the throttle ?ap disturbance. We can distinguish ice in closing and opening
throttle ?ap direction.
The ice shall be removed with a variation of the setpoint for the digital position controller. If the ice-breaking
is not possible then the throttle position setpoint will be limited in lower or upper direction depends on the
detected ice location.

69.17.2.1 Function description
Auxiliary functions
The following section describes the deactivation condition and the continuously part of the ETC jam detection.
The aim is to control the state machine and the ice-breaking function.
The diagnostic conditions of the ETC jam detection are true as long as the general disable condition isn?t set.
The diagnosis distinguishes two types of present errors, the ?rst is a normal error only for the indication and the
other one shall indicate a safety critical error with ?nally fault reaction request (ETC power stage deactivation,
engine speed limitation). The error symptoms are de?ned for this diagnosis as:
Error symptoms are de?ned to this diagnosis function as following:
LV_SYM_TPS_JAM_CLOSE - TPS jammed in closing direction
LV_SYM_TPS_JAM_OPEN - TPS jammed in opening direction
LV_SYM_TPS_JAM_FSM - TPS jammed safety critically
State machine for ETC jam detection
This section describes the state machine of the ETC jam detection functionality. The state machine is used
for the coordination of the different requirements during the detection of jammed ETC throttle actuator. Ad-
ditionally the function manages all kind of requests to the remaining software system, that are engine speed
limitation, throttle position setpoint adjustment and the inhibition of selected functions. The state machine
distinguishes the following states:
STATE_TPS_JAM_DET Note
INIT The initialisation state initialises all important variables and checks the transition conditions
to the other states.
ICE_BREAK The ice-breaking state is used for an active breaking of ice in the throttle actuator. For this
case the throttle position setpoint is varied by a rectangle function. If the ice-breaking is not
successful after a de?ned number of rectangle pulses the function changes into the state
throttle position setpoint limitation. During the active ice-breaking engine speed limitation is
requested !
SP_LIMIT In the throttle position setpoint limitation state the ice-breaking was not successful or the
inhibition counter for ice-breaking isn?t yet expired. In this case the setpoint will be limited in
upper and lower direction. If the actual throttle position exceeds a de?ned threshold during
limitation in lower direction, then a additional error entry will be made with fault reaction:
ETC power stage switch-off and engine speed limitation.

� General Information
The following module described the application incidence of the ETC jam detection and should be used for
the control of the ice-breaking algorithm. The functionality is split in the engine speed monitoring and the
control conditions for the ETC jam detection as follows.

THRO, Electronic throttle control jam detection (Appl. Inc.)
ICE-Breaker Function con?guration: CLF_TPS_ICE_ACT_TYP
->0: ICE-Function start after Wake-up; Starter release after ICE-Breaking is ?nished; injection isn?t blocked
->1: ICE-Function start after KL15 on; Starter release after ICE-Breaking is ?nished; injection isn?t blocked
-> 2: ICE-Function start after KL15 on; Starter release is not stopped; No injection as long as ICE-breaking
is active

THRO, Electronic throttle control jam detection (Appl. Inc.)
69.18.2.1.2.1.1 Conditions for Throttle ice-breaking
Throttle Ice-detection conditions are determined in the below algorithm. The setting of ?ag?LV_TPS_ICE_CDN?
indicates that ice-conditions are detection and ice-breaking function is active.
The ice detection ?ag ?LV_TPS_ICE_CDN?is active after reset.
The variable LV_TPS_ICE_CDN can only be set to 0 in the below algorithm.
The below algorithm can?t setLV_TPS_ICE_CDN from 0 to 1 again.
The ice breaking starts if CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN>C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_START.
For the calibration of C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_START, the time to move the TPS from LIH position at reset into
the new position TPS_SP_ICE, has to be considered.
The end of the ice breaking is de?ned with C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_END
Also, C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_END must be calibrated >C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_START, for ice-breaking function
to be working.
Please note, that C_TPS_AV_ICE_CDN, the threshold for ice sticking condition, should be set at higher value
than C_TPS_SP_ICE.
The ICE-function is disabled, if the max. value (C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PLS_ACT) of JAM-cycles are reached.

� General Information
This module describes the generation of the throttle position setpoint for the closed-loop digital position con-
trol. All throttle position setpoint requests delivered from the remaining software system are collected, co-
ordinated and ?nally limited. At the end the ETC setpoint selection the setpoint for the ETC digital position
controller is provided.
The described functionality consists of the throttle position setpoint selection, the support of the ETC jam
detection and the setpoint limitation of physical throttle position range.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Deactivation: never or if activation-condition of other event is true
Recurrence: 5MS activated if LV_TPS_AD_ACT==1
10MS activated if LV_TPS_AD_ACT==0

69.19.2.1 Throttle position setpoint selection
The task of this function is to collect and to select the throttle position setpoint for the digital position controller.
The ?nal setpoint is selected dependent on the engine states, further requests are de?ned in the corresponding
application incidences.
The unlimited throttle position setpoint is selected from the following requests:
Setpoint request during ice-breaking activation: TPS_SP_ICE
The TPS limp-home position is requested: TPS_SP_LIH
Setpoint request during post operating phase: TPS_SP_POP

THRO, Electronic throttle control setpoint selection
Setpoint request during TPS adaptation: TPS_SP_AD
Setpoint request during Cleaning function: TPS_SP_CLE
External setpoint request e.g. application system: TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ
Setpoint for Backwards rotation: TPS_SP_ENG_BACK_DET
Setpoint request during engine start: TPS_SP_ST
Setpoint request during engine stop: TPS_SP_ES
Setpoint request from the inverse intake manifold model: TPS_SP_MDL
After the motor start the throttle position setpoint is switched from the start value to the setpoint provided by
the inverse intake manifold model by the following transfer function. The transient phase compensates the
deviation between the last start setpoint request and the model value and starts if the start phase is switched-
off.

69.19.2.2 Throttle position setpoint request during ETC jam detection
During LV_TPS_SP_JAM = 1 the throttle position setpoint for electronic throttle control is delivered by the ETC
jam detection functionality. After ?nishing of the function, the request is set to zero and a transient phase
between TPS_SP_SEL and TPS_SP_JAM is started. In the transient phase the selected throttle position setpoint
is limited by maximum value TPS_SP_MAX in opening direction. The limitation threshold will be increased
with every iteration of the module "ETC setpoint selection". The transient phase will be ?nished if TPS_SP_MAX
reaches its maximum value. The setpoint limitation is only valid if a jammed ETC actuator in opening direction
has been detected.

69.19.2.3 Throttle position setpoint limitation
The task of this function is to limit the throttle position setpoint for the protection of the throttle actuator and
for a ef?cient electrical position sensor diagnosis. Therefore the module must be evaluated after the throttle
setpoint selection.
Dependent on the TPS adaptation status ( adapted or non-adapted throttle ?ap ) different thresholds for the
lower and upper limitation are used. When no adaptation is active the TPS set point is limited by the adapted
bottom limit. Additionally an interface is provided for the ETC jam detection to limit the throttle position set-
point in lower direction in case of the throttle ?ap is jammed by ice, the limitation is only active after successful
TPS adaptation. Finally, the gradient of the throttle position setpoint is limited in negative direction if its value
is below the low speed point.

� Import actions:
ACTION_FCTM_HoldPwlPhase(IN <PRM_IDX_PWL_LOCK_CDN>)
ACTION_FCTM_ReleasePwlPhase(IN <PRM_IDX_PWL_LOCK_CDN>)
� General Information
The following module shall provide all remaining ETC setpoint requests for every engine operating state. At
the end of function the ETC power stage deactivation condition requested from the ETC setpoint selection
is calculated. The aim is to preserve the vehicle electrical system during the engine standstill. Therefore this
module must be calculated before the chapter ETC position controller (application incidences ) !

At
the end of function the ETC power stage deactivation condition requested from the ETC setpoint selection
is calculated. The aim is to preserve the vehicle electrical system during the engine standstill. Therefore this
module must be calculated before the chapter ETC position controller (application incidences ) !
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON, IGKOFF
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

69.20.2.1 ETC setpoint during engine stop
The ETC setpoint during engine standstill can be used for the pre-positioning of the throttle ?ap before the
engine is started. After a de?ned time without engine start, the setpoint request should be removed to preserve
the vehicle electric system, that means the ETC power stage shall be deactivated.

69.20.2.3 ETC setpoint during limp-home request
The following ETC setpoint is used for the request of a de?ned ETC limp-home position. Usually the setpoint is
the default position of the throttle actuator with deactivated power stage. But with activated power stage it is
also possible to de?ne any other limp-home position for the ETC setpoint. This kind of functionality is required
by monitoring level.

69.20.2.4 ETC switch-off request by ETC setpoint selection
The main task of this chapter is to preserve the vehicle electric system during the engine standstill. The ETC
power stage will be deactivated if no setpoint request is available. All kinds of requests demanded from the
ETC setpoint selection must be considered.

69.20.2.6 ETC setpoint during post operating phase
To avoid that with ignition off the current-less throttle is set to the limp home position at once, for a tunable time
period a throttle position setpoint during the post operating phase is available. The function shall guarantee
that the throttle is driven to a de?ned ?ap position before the ETC power stage is switched-off. If the power
stage is already deactivated when ignition off is detected then it shouldn t be activated again.

69.20.2.9.1 Throttle cleaning function enabled
During Cleaning, the throttle moves to a CLOSE-position: C_TPS_SP_CLE_CLOSE
(starts after a the timer T_DLY_TPS_CLE reach C_T_DLY_CLE_CLOSE)
This closing-duration could be calibrated with C_T_DLY_TPS_CLE_OPEN.

After reaching of this threshold the actuator moves to open-position: C_TPS_SP_CLE_OPEN.
This position is active as long as the timer reach C_T_DLY_TPS_CLE_OFF.
At this point the actuator will move to end-position (C_TPS_SP_CLE_OFF)
with a ramp (C_TPS_SP_CLE_LGRD_OFF).
With ending of the CLE-function the actuator is switched off.

� General Information
The aim of this module is to control an electrical throttle actuator according to the function principle DC
motor + gear. The closed-loop position control system consists of the throttle actuator with integrated position
measurement system, the throttle position sensor signal acquisition based on signal processing and throttle
angle determination, the ETC power stage and the digital position controller with static compensation.
� Application Conditions
Initialization: RST
Recurrence: 1MS, 10MS
Activation: always
Deactivation: never

69.21.2.1 ETC position control algorithm
This section describes the functional part of the ETC position controller calculated with a recurrence of 2 ms.
The position controller is carried out as a robust digital position controller. Calibration data are determined
according to Continental internal controller design. The position controller consists of a transfer function
for the decoupling between static and dynamic behaviour and adaptive controller ampli?cation in forward
direction and an additional phase correction in backward direction to in?uence the system damping.
To avoid additional delay between AD conversion and calculation it is necessary that the routines for calcula-
tion of TPS_ETC and PWM_ETC are called directly after the AD conversion is ?nished. The Output of PWM_ETC
starts immediately after its calculation.

69.21.3 Functional part of 10 ms
This section describes the functional part of the ETC position controller calculated with a recurrence of 10
ms.
The circuit ampli?cation of the closed-loop position control system should be held constantly; therefore the
position controller ampli?cation is calculated dependent on the battery voltage adaptively. Additionally the
maximum input value of the PT1 part of the transfer function is determined dependent on the corrected
controller ampli?cation.

69.21.3.1 Compensation of the system deviation
This function compensates the static control deviation of the throttle position controller. Therefore it must be
evaluated after the ETC setpoint selection and limitation. The digital position controller operates without inte-
grator but with a high circuit ampli?cation, consequently the position control has a small system deviation.

THRO, Electronic throttle control position control (gen)
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_VP_TPS_GAIN_1_DI Security deactivation threshold for the ampli?ed TPS 1 channel, the value depend on the
maximum output of the measuring ampli?er and tolerance of the AD conversion ! The
value shall guarantee that the ampli?ed channel can be deactivated in all engine operating
states. Usually the maximum value of the ampli?ed channel is higher than 4.8 V (worst
case calculation) !
C_TPS_GAIN_1_DI The disable threshold de?ned the working range of the ampli?ed TPS channel. The
ampli?ed TPS channel shall only be active during the engine idle speed. Recommend
value of the disable threshold should be lower than 6 �TPS.
C_TPS_GAIN_1_ENA Activation threshold for the selection of the ampli?ed TPS 1 channel, the value must be
chosen lower than the corresponding disable threshold. A signal hysteresis between
activation and deactivation of about 1 �TPS or greater is recommend !
C_VP_TPS_GRD The constant described the resolution of the used AD converter dependent on a reference
voltage of 5 V.
10 bit ADC: C_VP_TPS_GRD = 0x20H = 4.883 mV
12 bit ADC: C_VP_TPS_GRD = 0x08H = 1.221 mV
C_TPS_GAIN_DIF_MAX The described threshold de?nes the admissible deviation between ampli?ed and
non-ampli?ed TPS channel. The admissible deviation should be smaller than 1 �TPS.
C_CTR_INC_TPS_GAIN_CHK
C_CTR_MAX_TPS_GAIN_CHK
Calibrate the increment value with 2 and the maximum value with 40 for the plausibility
check between ampli?ed and non-ampli?ed channel. The corresponding debounce time is
40 ms ( 20 time samples).
C_TPS_MAX Chose the maximum possible throttle position, the value is used only for the initialisation
and in case of detected TPS double error ! The recommend value for a standard actuator
is 80 �TPS.
� ETC setpoint selection
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TPS_SP_JAM_LGRD The constant is a functional part of the ice-breaking function described in the module ETC
jam detection. The change limitation of the throttle position setpoint is used after
ice-breaking in open throttle ?ap direction has been requested. A recommend value for the
rate limitation of the throttle position setpoint is 0.02 �TPS per sample, that are 2 �TPS / s.
C_TPS_SP_MIN Threshold for lower setpoint limitation, the value should not be smaller than 0.5 �TPS
C_TPS_SP_MIN_TPS_AD_REQ The threshold for the lower setpoint limitation is only valid during TPS adaptation request,
the value must be calibrate to 0 � TPS

Calibration label Calibration advice
C_KP_ETC The controller ampli?cation should be chosen in a range between 90 and 120 % / �TPS at
battery reference voltage. With too high ampli?cation the throttle ?ap can swing with a
amplitude of approximately 0.1 �TPS as result of the 10 bit AD conversion process. It should
be tried to set the ampli?cation as high as possible.
C_KDF_ETC The value of the difference ampli?cation should be chosen with 5 to 8 usually. A no-periodic
behaviour without oscillation and overshooting of the throttle ?ap has to be obtained.
The effect of the system damping can be checked with the step response method in large
and small signal range.
C_FAC_0_FIL_ETC The constant describes the b0 parameter of the below mentioned transfer function.
C_FAC_1_FIL_ETC The constant describes the a1 parameter of the below mentioned transfer function.
IP_FAC_VB_ETC The correction factor dependent on the battery voltage is approximated by a characteristic
line with two data points.
To avoid too high ampli?cation values the data points are used to limit the correction value.
With nominal value of the battery voltage (engine is running) the correction factor should
be 1.
C_KDF_PRE_FIL_ETC The constant increases or decreases the setpoint request for a short time step to
compensate the coulomb friction in the closed loop system during small setpoint steps.
C_TPS_MAX_PRE_FIL_ETC The described threshold limits the output of the dynamic pre-?lter in lower and upper
direction. The value is used to prevent a over-compensation of the coulomb friction in the
closed - loop system. A recommend value for the calibration is 0.3 � TPS.
C_KI_ETC The integration speed of the static integrator should be chosen slow in comparison to the
dynamic of the position controller. C_KI_ETC should be 0.01 to 0.025.
C_TPS_DIF_MAX The integrator is activated only in the operating range |TPS_DIF| <C_TPS_DIF_MAX
otherwise its state variable is initialised with C_TPS_INT_INI. The value should be calibrated
with 1 �TPS, a calibration of 0 �TPS deactivated the integrator.

THRO, Electronic throttle control position control (gen)
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TPS_INT_INI The initialisation value depend on the spring stiffness of the ETC actuator and the position
controller ampli?cation. A static pre-load of about 20 % PWM should be chosen by nominal
values, that means C_TPS_INT_INI = 20 % / C_KP_ETC.
C_TPS_OFS_CTL_MAX The limitation value has to be calibrated under consideration of the controller
ampli?cation. Under nominal conditions the calibration should not exceed 50 % PWM
controller output, that means:
C_TPS_OFS_CTL_MAX = 50 % / C_KP_ETC
C_TPS_LIH_HYS The linear hysteresis around the limp-home position is de?ned by the maximum limitation
value and the transition range, see the upper ?gure. The hysteresis range should be
chosen in a range of about 0.6 �TPS depend on the maximum limitation value.

Calibration label Calibration advice
C_PV_MIN_EXT_ADJ Pedal value threshold for an additional activation and de-activation of the external setpoint
adjustment, only active when requested by C_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ_ENA !
C_T_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ The waiting period after an external request by PV before the TPS is shut off. A value of
0,3s is recommended.

Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TIA_THD_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ The temperature threshold for activating the additional factor on external setpoint.
C_TPS_SP_AS_MAN Manual external setpoint request only used when requested by C_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ_ENA
C_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ_ENA Activation constant for external setpoint adjustment:
0 - external setpoint adjustment isn?t requested
1 - setpoint adjustment via calibration constant
>1 - setpoint adjustment dependent on pedal value
C_TPS_SP_POP_LGRD Gradient limitation in the post operating phase between IP_TPS_SP_POP and
C_TPS_SP_POP_UP setpoint. The value can be calibrated with 0.5 �TPS/10 ms and must not
be calibrated to zero.
C_TPS_SP_POP_UP Throttle position during post operating phase before the ETC power stage is switched-off.
The throttle ?ap should be set in the limp-home position before deactivation.
IP_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ External setpoint request dependent on PV only active when requested by
C_TPS_SP_EXT_ADJ_ENA. Additionally the setpoint is only activated when PV exceeds the
PV threshold C_PV_MIN_EXT_ADJ
IP_TPS_SP_POP Setpoint request after ignition off and before engine stopped is detected. The characteristic
line depends on the engine speed and should be calibrated with consideration of the
manifold pressure. The characteristic shall prevent too low pressures within the intake
manifold and is used for fast stop of the engine.

THRO, Electronic throttle control jam detection (gen)
69.25 Electronic throttle control jam detection (gen)
� General Information:
� Calibration Interfering Functions
The calibration of the ETC jam detection should be done after the calibration of the position controller and
the actuator diagnosis. Furthermore the described functionality stands in interaction with the continuously
adaptation of the lower mechanical stop.
� Calibration Flowchart:
The sequence is described by the order in calibrated methods.
� Calibration Process:
� Auxiliary values
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TPS_JAM_OFS The constant is used for the determination of the pulse generator starting point and the
throttle position setpoint limitation threshold. The offset value is added in closing and
subtracted in opening throttle ?ap direction to the position of ice-detection. Usually the
value can be set to 0.5 �TPS.
C_TPS_JAM_HYS The calibration constant is used for the deactivation of the ice-breaking function. If the
throttle position or the throttle position setpoint leave the hysteresis area around the
position of ice-detection than the ice function will be deactivated. A recommend value is 1.0
� TPS.
Note: The constant must be calibrated with consideration of the pulse height from the
pulse generator. In case of ice-detection the pulse generator must be able to exceed the
deactivation thresholds !
Active ice-breaking in closing direction:
(The same ice-breaking meachnism could be calibrated in
opening direction: see labels for ?opening? ):

THRO, Electronic throttle control jam detection (gen)
Calibration label Calibration advice
Figure 69.25.1:
C_TPS_JAM_MAX If ice-breaking in closing direction is not successful than the diagnosis threshold de?nes
the maximum admissible throttle position for the setpoint limitation. A safety critical error
will be indicated if the throttle position exceeds the threshold. Usually the calibration
constant is set to the throttle ?ap limp-home position e.g. 5 �TPS.
� Pulse generator
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_TPS_JAM_PLS_OPEN
C_TPS_JAM_PLS_CLOSE
The constants describe the height of the rectangle pulses used for active ice-breaking.
Both variables refer to the initial setpoint calculated dependent on the position of
ice-detection. We can calibrate different pulse heights dependent on ice position in closing
or opening throttle ?ap direction, recommend values are:
C_TPS_JAM_PLS_OPEN = 5 �TPS
C_TPS_JAM_PLS_CLOSE = 5 �TPS
C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PER_OPEN
C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PER_CLOSE
The next two calibration constants de?ne the pulse width of the rectangle pulse sequence.
We can calibrate different widths dependent on ice detection in closing or opening throttle
direction, recommend values are:
C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PER_OPEN = 5 (50 ms)
C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PER_CLOSE = 5 (50 ms)
The pulse width should not be chosen too small, because the position controller has to be
able to adjust the requested throttle position setpoint.
C_TPS_JAM_LGRD_OPEN
C_TPS_JAM_LGRD_CLOSE
The rectangle pulse in the ice-breaking direction (no ramping for the other direction) could
be ramped with an gradient. This could be use to reduce the mechanical stress for the
throttle. Recommend is 1�TPS

� General Information:
The sequence is described by the order in calibrated methods.
� Calibration Interfering Functions
The calibration of the ETC jam detection should be done after the
calibration of the position controller and the actuator diagnosis.
Furthermore the described functionality stands in interaction
with the continuously adaptation of the lower mechanical stop.
� Calibration Flowchart:
� Calibration Process:
� Filtered Battery Voltage
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_CRLC_VB_TPS_ICE_CDN
C_VB_FIL_TPS_ICE_ENA
C_VB_INI_TPS_ICE_CDN
Below the de?ned battery voltage the ETC jam detection is not activated. A recommend

Filtering co-ef?cient: Set to 0.3
� Activation conditions
Calibration label Calibration advice
CLF_TPS_ICE_ACT_TYP Can be used to deactivate the ICE-function or to con?gure the start of the function and the
behaviour of injection/starter activation (description see in 30C01103)
IP_TIA_MAX_TPS_JAM The aim of the characteristic line is to inhibit the ETC jam detection at high intake manifold
air temperatures. Calibrate the threshold to 0�C at high temperatures of the engine and
increase the threshold with falling TCO.
C_CTR_TPS_JAM_PLS_ACT Threshold for max. ICE-pulse over lifetime (counter could be reseted via tester): if the pulse

C_N_TPS_ICE_ENA Engine speed threshold for deactivation of ICE-function: set 32rpm

C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_START ICE-activation start: timer runs after lv_tps_ice_cnd 0->1: value depends on C_TPS_SP_ICE
(end-setpoint value of ICE-check) and the gradient C_TPS_JAM_LGRD_CLOSE/OPEN
(gradient to reach the end-setpoint): recommended 20
C_CTR_TPS_ICE_CDN_END Absolute end-time for the ICE-function (only reached if no other stop criteria will be
activated (e.g.: max pulse counter reached; ICE breaking successful..)): set to 200
C_TPS_AV_ICE_CDN If the actual throttle value (TPS_AV) reached this position: no ICE is detected ->stop
function: set to 2�TPS

Calibration label Calibration advice
LC_TPS_AD_LIH_ENA Logical constant allows to activate the continuously adaptation of the limp-home position.
LC_TPS_AD_GAIN_ENA The logical constant allows to adapting the measuring ampli?er of TPS 1. The constant
depend on the hardware con?guration of the engine control unit and must be calibrated to
zero at systems without measuring ampli?er, otherwise errors will be indicated.
LC_TPS_SP_AD_GAIN_ENA The logical constant allows to calculate the throttle valve position setpoint for the upper
reference point during the adaptation of the measuring ampli?er.
� Initialisation values of the TPS adaptation
Any projects use in the engine idle speed area a high resolution position sensor signal. To provide this resolu-
tion an extended input circuit is necessary. The sensor signal is ampli?ed by an analogue ampli?er mounted
on the ECU between position sensor and AD converter.

Those are the throttle ?ap nominal values of the lower mechanical stop. Both values are

C_VP_TPS_AD_BOL_INI_2
The initialisation values must guarantee that the position controller is able to drive the
throttle ?ap in the lower mechanical stop. The initialisation values are the result of the worst
case calculation made for the TPS measuring system. The value of TPS 1 must be lower
and the value of TPS 2 must be higher than the corresponding nominal values, for example
0.2V and 4.8V !
C_VP_TPS_SP_LIH_1

Those are the nominal values of the throttle ?ap limp-home position. The values are also
described in the technical actuator speci?cation.
C_TPS_AD_SLOP_GAIN_INI The nominal ampli?cation of the measuring ampli?er is de?ned in the data sheet of the
engine control unit. The constant is only valid with chosen functionality of the measuring
ampli?er see above LC_TPS_AD_GAIN_ENA.
C_VP_TPS_GAIN_AD_BOL_INI The initialisation value of the lower mechanical stop for the ampli?ed TPS 1 channel must
be calibrated as follows:
C_VP_TPS_AD_BOL_INI_1 * C_TPS_AD_SLOP_GAIN_INI
C_TPS_SLOP The throttle ?ap standard slop of the measuring system is de?ned in the data sheet of the
ETC actuator. Usually the recommend value is 21.0 �TPS / V

� Setpoints and change limitation
For example:
The setpoint must be calibrated with respect to the maximum ampli?er output. In current projects, the maxi-
mum output of the measuring ampli?er is approximately 4.8 V over temperature and lifetime (see data sheet).
With consideration of the maximum ampli?er output, the tolerances of the ampli?cation factor and the position
sensor signal slope, the greatest possible throttle position setpoint can be calculated as follows:
C_TPS_SP_RST_CHK = [ 4.8V / TPS_AD_SLOP_GAIN_1MAX ? 2 * C_VP_TPS_SP_BOL_1 +
C_VP_TPS_AD_BOL_INI_1 ] * TPS_SLOPMIN

Calibration label Calibration advice
C_VP_TPS_AD_DIF_MAX Maximum change limitation for learned values from time delayed TPS adaptation. Should
be calibrated with about 0,025V.
C_VP_TPS_AD_WIN_BOL Maximum permitted tolerance window of the lower mechanical stop, valid during the BOL
adaptation, the value must be the result of the tolerance calculation made for the
measuring system. Usually the value lies in a range of 0.3V.
C_VP_TPS_AD_WIN_LIH Maximum permitted tolerance window of the limp-home position before adaptation, the
value must be the result of the tolerance calculation made for the measuring system.
Usually the value lies in a range of 0.3V
C_VP_TPS_LIH_CHK_HYS Maximum permitted tolerance window of the limp-home position after adaptation
(repetition accuracy), the value is used for the check of the limp-home position. The value
is lower than the value before adaptation (e.g. 0.18 V).
C_VP_TPS_AD_HYS The hysteresis window is used for the detection of a stationary operation point, that means
the throttle has to stand in a steady position (see picture). The constant should be
calibrated with 0.01 to 0.02V.
C_TPS_SP_RST_CHK_HYS The diagnosis during the return spring checks shall monitor the correct working of the
throttle actuator drive. The hysteresis window depend on the requested throttle position
and should be calibrated lower than 0.5 �TPS
C_TPS_AD_SLOP_GAIN_MIN
C_TPS_AD_SLOP_GAIN_MAX
The ampli?cation of the measuring ampli?er must be in a de?ned range, otherwise the
diagnosis function indicates adaptation errors. The admissible range is de?ned by the
tolerance calculation of the measuring ampli?er and the accuracy of the software
calculation.

Calibration label Calibration advice
C_T_DLY_MIN_TPS_AD The described time delay is used to get a plausible battery voltage for the TPS adaptation.
The time counter starts with ignition on and can be ?nished with external request if the
counter exceeds the de?ned threshold. Usually the value is calibrated to 80 ms.
C_T_DLY_TPS_AD The threshold de?ned the maximum time delay for a valid battery voltage and is used to
synchronize the adaptation functionality with the determination of the battery voltage after
system reset. The adaptation shall only be active after ECM 3 pre-drive check! The value
should be calibrated smaller than 1 s.
C_CRLC_TPS_AD The correlation constant is used for the calculation of the moving mean values used for
determination of the TPS adaptation values. The ?lter rate of the ?lter algorithm is
increased with falling correlation constant. The constant must be calibrated with
consideration of the adaptation interval C_T_TPS_AD_HYS.
C_T_MAX_TPS_LIH_CHK The maximum permitted diagnosis time during the LIH check should be calibrated greater
than 0.6 s.
C_T_DYW_TPS_LIH_CHK The condition for the check of the limp-home position must be ful?lled for a de?ned time,
chose the value with approximately 0.1 s
C_T_TPS_AD_HYS Time for the detection of a stationary operation point, during this time the throttle ?ap
must stand in a steady position, the value can be chosen with 0.1 s.
C_T_MAX_TPS_AD The maximum permitted time during the adaptation step diagnosis should be chosen
greater than 0.6 s.
C_T_MAX_TPS_SP_RST_CHK The maximum diagnosis time during the return spring checks should be chosen greater
than 0.6 s.

THRO, Electronic throttle control adaptation diagnosis (prj)
Calibration label Calibration advice
C_CUR_ETC_DR_TPS_AD The power stage monitoring compares the requested and the actual power stage state
(enable or disable) dependent on the different TPS adaptation steps TPS_AD_STEP. In the
described constant all states of the ETC power stage during the TPS adaptation and start
check are bit-coded.
C_N_MAX_TPS_AD The greatest possible engine speed is de?ned by customer requiremnets or the starter
speed. Remark: The injection is disabled during the TPS adaptation, a threshold of 192 rpm
is usually recommended.
C_PV_MAX_TPS_AD The TPS adaptation is active if PV is below this threshold. A threshold of 5% is usually
recommended.
C_TIA_MIN_TPS_AD
C_TCO_MIN_TPS_AD
C_TCO_MAX_TPS_AD
The ambient conditions of the TPS adaptation are de?ned in the actuator speci?cation,
read the data sheet for the correct calibration, recommend values are:
C_TIA_MIN_TPS_AD = 5 �C
C_TCO_MIN_TPS_AD = 5 �C
C_TCO_MAX_TPS_AD = 100 �C
C_T_TPS_AD_DLY After this time the time delayed TPS adaptation is started. A time of about 60s is usually
recommended.
C_VB_MIN_TPS_AD De?nition of the smallest permitted battery voltage. The TPS adaptation and also the start
check are activated after IGKON with the time delay C_T_DLY_TPS_AD to get a plausible
battery voltage, a recommend value is 10V.
C_VS_MAX_TPS_AD The TPS adaptation is active below this vehicle speed threshold. A value of 2km/h is
recommended.
C_CTR_ERR_CUR_ETC_DR The debounce counter is necessary for the correct working of ETC power stage - state
monitoring. The problem is the time scheduling between TPS adaptation and power stage
activation/deactivation in different OSEK tasks, therefore a debounce time of at least 20 ms
should be calibrated, that means the constant has to be set to 4 !
LC_TPS_AD_REQ The TPS adaptation can be requested by a manual request via calibration system. After the
request, the adaptation will be activated with IGKON. The adaptation request is set with
transition from 0 to 1 of LC_TPS_AD_REQ !
LC_TPS_AD_REQ_DLY The time delayed TPS adaptation is activated with LC_TPS_AD_REQ_DLY = 1

IP_TPS_REL_ST_AT
In the ?rst step the throttle position at start is set to the throttle position at idle speed after start. Therefore
starts at the selected TCO breakpoints are necessary. The measured reduced area after start in stable idle
operation is used to calibrate both characteristic lines (measured value as percentage of maximal reduced
area).
In the next step the engine speed overshoot at start has to be tuned. Repeat the engine start at the selected
TCO breakpoint until the overshoot is in the considered height:
If the over shoot is to small increase IP_TPS_SP_REL_ST_MT/AT in the following way:
? increase the value at low engine speed breakpoints with the same offset
(LDPM_N_1_THRO = 0, 250)
? do not increase at engine speed breakpoints ?idle speed setpoint
? form a linear dependency for all other breakpoints in-between

? If the overshoot is too big reduce IP_TPS_SP_REL_ST_MT/AT in the similar way:
? decrease the value at low engine speed breakpoints with the same offset
(LDPM_N_1_THRO = 0, 250)
? do not change the values at engine speed breakpoints ?idle speed setpoint
? form a linear dependency for all other breakpoints in-between
For warm engines the overshoot is often too high even if IP_TPS_SP_REL_ST is zero at the ?rst two engine speed
breakpoints. Therefore it?s useful to keep the throttle closed also for the next engine speed breakpoints.
Remark: It?s not useful to calibrate a completely closed throttle because the throttle may
clamp in this position.
If the overshoot is still to high it?s not possible to decrease the overshoot by controlling the mass air?ow. In this
case the ignition during start has to be retarded.
In the next step the course of the manifold air pressure (MAP) is considered to improve the calibration. Mainly
for high engine speed overshoots a MAP undershoot will follow. Generally this undershoot is often necessary
to activate the brake power assist unit. But in some cases the undershoot is too big and may lead to a bad
engine speed behaviour after start (undershoot ? oscillation). So in this case the throttle has to be opened
during the overshoot. Therefore the linear engine speed dependency has to be lengthened but not with the
same slope:

## Function

The diagram depicts the functional architecture of the Electronic Throttle Control (ETC) system, specifically focusing on the limp-home management function. It illustrates how the system controls the throttle flap position based on driver demand and engine operating conditions, while also incorporating safety and diagnostic features.  The core function is to maintain safe and controlled engine operation even in the presence of faults, by adjusting the throttle position or initiating fault reactions.

## Inputs

*   **System fault reaction request:**  (engine power reduction, engine speed limitation, power stage deactivation) - Indicates the need for a specific fault reaction based on detected issues.
*   **ETC setpoint calculation at start:** Provides initial setpoint for the throttle.
*   **ETC throttle angle variables:** Contains data such as throttle position.
*   Implicit input is driver demand from the ECU, to command a throttle position.
*   Signals from ETC sensors, checked for plausibility.

## Outputs

*   **H-bridge driver, BSW:**  Control signal sent to the H-bridge driver, which ultimately controls the ETC motor (throttle actuator). This is the main output for controlling the throttle position.
*   **Adaptation values:** Used by ETC actuator adaptation diagnosis.
*   **Deactivation request:** Sent by the ETC limp-home management module for deactivating the H-bridge driver.

## Logic Flow

1.  **ETC Setpoint Calculation at Start:** Initializes the desired throttle position (ETC setpoint).
2.  **ETC Throttle Angle Variables:** The throttle position is monitored.
3.  **ETC Sensor Plausibility Check and ETC Position Sensor Diagnosis:** Sensors are monitored for faults. Any issues detected are forwarded to the ETC limp-home management.
4.  **ETC Actuator Diagnosis and ETC Power Stage Diagnosis:** The actuator and power stage are monitored for faults.
5.  **ETC Limp-Home Management:** This is the central module. It receives inputs from:
    *   System fault reaction request.
    *   ETC sensor plausibility check.
    *   ETC position sensor diagnosis.
    *   ETC actuator diagnosis.
    *   ETC power stage diagnosis.

## Function

The Simulink diagram implements a bit filter for throttle position sensor (TPS) signals, specifically designed to address issues arising from the AD conversion process. The AD values of the throttle position sensors have a resolution of 10 bits (1024 increments) according to the AD converter. The smallest signification bit, one increment, is the fault of the AD conversion process and this bit can alternate from conversion to conversion. To compensate this fault a bit filter is used. It takes raw TPS signals as input and outputs filtered TPS signals. The system accounts for normal and amplified channels for TPS1.

## Inputs

*   `<ACTION_INFR_GetVTps_T3>`: Raw input containing information from the throttle position sensors. This input provides several sub-signals:
    *   `PRM_VP_TPS_1_BAS`: Raw TPS signal from sensor 1.
    *   `PRM_VP_TPS_2_BAS`: Raw TPS signal from sensor 2.
*   `<VP_TPS_1_BAS>` from figure 69.4.4 fed into figure 69.4.5 for bit filtering.

## Outputs

*   `VP_TPS_1_FIL`: Filtered TPS signal from sensor 1.
*   `VP_TPS_2_FIL`: Filtered TPS signal from sensor 2.
*   `clc_vp_tps`: some other output.

## Logic Flow

The overall structure is as follows:

1.  **Input Acquisition:** The `ActionImport` block labeled `<ACTION_INFR_GetVTps_T3>` receives the raw throttle position sensor data. This data includes the raw signals `PRM_VP_TPS_1_BAS` and `PRM_VP_TPS_2_BAS`.

2.  **Bit Filtering (TPS1):**  The block labeled `Bit_filter_TPS_1 X.2.1.1` performs bit filtering on the `VP_TPS_1_BAS` signal.
   *  Figure 69.4.5 elaborates on the logic within `Bit_filter_TPS_1 X.2.1.1`.

        a. `<VP_TPS_1_BAS>` is inputted into a gain of 1/z (V.5.3)
        b. The output of the gain is compared to '0' through two comparisons. One `>` (V.5.5) and the other `<` (V.5.5).

        c. Then, depending on the conditions (V.6.0), the output `VP_TPS_1_BAS` or `C_VP_TPS_GRD` are used in a merge block (V.6.7)

        d. V.6.7 sums the original `<VP_TPS_1_BAS>` with `VP_TPS_1_BAS` or `C_VP_TPS_GRD`.

        e. The result is then merged to become `VP_TPS_1_FIL`

3.  **Bit Filtering (TPS2):** The block labeled `Bit_filter_TPS_2 X.2.1.2` performs bit filtering on the `VP_TPS_2_BAS` signal. While the internal logic for this block isn't explicitly shown, it's likely similar to the TPS1 filter, perhaps with different parameters or a slightly modified structure.

## Inputs

*   **\<VP\_TPS\_2\_BAS\>**:  Raw, unfiltered voltage signal from the Throttle Position Sensor 2.
*   **C\_VP\_TPS\_GRD**:  A threshold or ground voltage level (likely a constant) used for comparison, possibly to detect sensor drift or failure.
*   **V.5.2**: A value subtracted from C\_VP\_TPS\_GRD.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Input Signal:** The raw TPS2 voltage signal, `VP_TPS_2_BAS`, enters the system.
2.  **Difference Calculation**: The input signal `VP_TPS_2_BAS` is used to calculate a difference, which is then delayed by one time step via the `1/z` block.
3.  **Comparison 1 (High Threshold):** The delayed signal is compared to a constant value `0` (V.5.5). If the delayed signal is *greater than* `0`, `cond if (V.6.0)` outputs the raw TPS2 signal `VP_TPS_2_BAS`. Otherwise, it outputs the value from the 'else' branch, which seems to be zero in this case.
4.  **Comparison 2 (Low Threshold):** The delayed signal is compared to a constant value `0` (V.5.5). If the delayed signal is *less than* `0`, `cond if (V.6.0)` outputs the ground voltage level `C_VP_TPS_GRD`. Otherwise, it outputs the value from the 'else' branch, which seems to be zero in this case.
5.  **Subtraction from Ground Reference**: The constant `V.5.2` is subtracted from `C_VP_TPS_GRD`.
6.  **Summation**: The results of `cond if` blocks are summed using two adders V.6.7 blocks.
7.  **Merge**:  The summation is then merged to obtain a filter output which is then passed to a filter.
8.  **Output:** The final filtered TPS2 voltage signal, `VP_TPS_2_FIL`, is the output of the system.

In essence, this diagram implements a filter that uses comparisons based on delayed value to either pass the raw TPS2 signal or substitute it with a ground reference value or a zero value depending on whether certain conditions are met. ## Function

The Simulink diagrams depict two different calculations for the short circuit state of an electronic throttle control (ETC) system's power stage. The first diagram (Figure 69.7.37) calculates the short circuit state *in the case of* an "ERR_SYM" (likely an error symbol condition). The second diagram (Figure 69.7.38) calculates the short circuit state *in the case of no* "ERR_SYM". Both diagrams ultimately produce a single output, `PRM_STATE_FIL`, which represents the filtered short circuit state.

## Inputs

**Figure 69.7.37 (ERR_SYM Case):**

*   `ABC_ETC_DR_SC`: Short circuit diagnostic signal
*   `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_DR`: Calibrated maximum ETC drive
*   `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_old`: Previous short circuit diagnostic signal

**Figure 69.7.38 (No ERR_SYM Case):**

*   `ABC_ETC_DR_SC`: Short circuit diagnostic signal
*   `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_DR`: Calibrated maximum ETC drive
*   `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_OLD`: Previous short circuit diagnostic signal

## Outputs

**Both Diagrams:**

*   `PRM_STATE_FIL`: Filtered short circuit state. It takes on different values depending on the calculations performed.

## Logic Flow

**Figure 69.7.37 (ERR_SYM Case):**

1.  **Minimum Calculation:** The `min` block calculates the minimum value between `ABC_ETC_DR_SC` and `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_DR`.
2.  **Equality and Inequality Checks:** The minimum value is compared for equality with `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_old`.  Simultaneously, `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_old` is checked if it is *not equal* to zero. Also, zero is checked whether it is less than or equal to the same input `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_old`.
3.  **AND Logic:** The results of the equality and inequality checks are fed into an `AND` block.  This means both conditions must be true for the `AND` block to output true (1).
4.  **Conditional Subsystem (Fcn_Call):** The output of the `AND` block drives a conditional subsystem (`cond_if`).

    *   **If the `AND` output is true (1):** The `FAIL` state (=2.0) is selected.
    *   **Else (if the `AND` output is false (0):** The  `INTM` state (=3.0) is selected.

5.

4.  **Conditional Subsystem (Fcn_Call):** The output of the `AND` block drives a conditional subsystem (`cond_if`).

    *   **If the `AND` output is true (1):** The `FAIL` state (=2.0) is selected.
    *   **Else (if the `AND` output is false (0):** The  `INTM` state (=3.0) is selected.

5.  **Conditional Subsystem (Fcn_Call):** The output of the `less than or equal` check block drives a conditional subsystem (`cond_if`).
6.  **Else (if the `less than or equal` check output is false (0):** The  `NO_EVE` state (=0.0) is selected.
7.  **Merge:**  The outputs of above two conditional systems are merged to produce a single output.
8.  **`PRM_STATE_FIL`:** This merged signal is the final output.

**Figure 69.7.38 (No ERR_SYM Case):**

1.  **Maximum Calculation:** The `max` block calculates the maximum value between `ABC_ETC_DR_SC` and `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_DR`. This value is then adjusted by the `+/-` block (which likely represents an offset or calibration factor, X.2.2.2.2.2.1).
2.  **Equality and Inequality Checks:** The adjusted maximum value is compared for equality with `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_OLD`. Simultaneously, `ABC_ETC_DR_SC_OLD` is checked if it is *not equal* to zero.
3.  **AND Logic:** The results of the equality and inequality checks are fed into an `AND` block.  This means both conditions must be true for the `AND` block to output true (1).
4.  **Conditional Subsystem (Fcn_Call):** The output of the `AND` block drives a conditional subsystem (`cond_if`).

    *   **If the `AND` output is true (1):** The `PASS` state (=1.0) is selected.
    *   **Else (if the `AND` output is false (0):** The `NO_EVE` state (=0.0) is selected.

5.  **Merge:** The output of the conditional subsystem is the input to a `Merge` block.
6.  **`PRM_STATE_FIL`:**  This merged signal is the final output.

## Function

The primary function of the diagram is to determine and output `LV_INH_DIAG_ETC_DR`, which represents the inhibition condition for the power stage diagnosis of the electronic throttle control, based on inputs such as the battery voltage (`VB`) and ignition signal (`LV_IGK`), and calibrated parameters like minimum battery voltage threshold (`C_VB_MIN_ETC_DR_DIAG`).  The diagram effectively implements a logic that disables or prevents the ETC power stage diagnosis under certain conditions, primarily based on the battery voltage level.

## Inputs

*   `VB` (Battery Voltage): The current battery voltage.
*   `LV_IGK` (Ignition On Signal):  Indicates whether the ignition is on.
*   `C_VB_MIN_ETC_DR_DIAG`: Calibration value for minimum battery voltage threshold below which the diagnostic is inhibited. This is technically a parameter, but it serves as an input within the diagram.

## Outputs

*   `LV_INH_DIAG_ETC_DR`: A flag (O/V) indicating whether the ETC power stage diagnosis should be inhibited. This signal is the output that is driven by the internal conditional logic.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization and Recurrence:** The function block is initialized during a reset (`RST`) or when the ignition is turned on (`IGKON`). The diagram is executed with a recurrence of 10ms. The block is always activated and never deactivated.

2.  **Inputs Processing**: The battery voltage `VB` and Ignition signal `LV_IGK` are inputs to a block labeled `input`. It's implied that the block `input` also receives the calibration data `C_VB_MIN_ETC_DR_DIAG`.

3.  **Conditional Logic (f())**: Inside the function block `f()`, a comparison is made between the measured battery voltage (`VB`) and the minimum voltage threshold `C_VB_MIN_ETC_DR_DIAG`.

4.  **Inhibition Condition**:
    *   If the battery voltage `VB` is *below* the calibrated minimum threshold `C_VB_MIN_ETC_DR_DIAG`, the `LV_INH_DIAG_ETC_DR` flag will be set to a value that inhibits the diagnostic. The value will be '1'.
    *   Conversely, if the battery voltage `VB` is *above* the calibrated minimum threshold, the `LV_INH_DIAG_ETC_DR` flag will be set to a value that allows the diagnostic to run. The value will be '0'.

5.  **Output**: The value of `LV_INH_DIAG_ETC_DR` is then outputted.

In summary, the diagram represents a system that monitors the battery voltage and, if it falls below a specified threshold, inhibits the ETC power stage diagnostic. This is likely done to prevent false positives or unreliable diagnostic results when the battery voltage is low.

## Function

This Simulink diagram describes two functions. The first (top) filters an Electronic Throttle Control (ETC) Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) signal when no symptoms are present.  The second (bottom) records errors related to ETC PWM 1.

## Inputs

### Filter Section (Top)

*   `C_ABC_DEC_ETC_PWM`: Decreasing ETC PWM signal
*   `C_ABC_INC_ETC_PWM`: Increasing ETC PWM signal
*   `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_PWM_2`: Maximum ETC PWM signal (2)
*   `[ABC_ETC_PWM]`: Current ETC PWM signal (feedback)
*   `ABC_ETC_PWMMin`: Minimum allowed ETC PWM signal
*   `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_PWM_1`: Maximum ETC PWM signal (1)

### Error Recording Section (Bottom)

*   `ACTION_ERRM_Record`: Trigger to record an error.
*   `NC_IDX_ERR_ETC_PWM_1`: Error index related to ETC PWM 1.
*   `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_1`: Filter state related to ETC PWM 1.

## Outputs

### Filter Section (Top)

*   `ABC_ETC_PWM`: Filtered ETC PWM signal.
*   `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_2`: Filter state signal (2).
*   `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_1`: Filter state signal (1).

### Error Recording Section (Bottom)

*   `PRM_IDX_ERR`: Error Index Parameter.
*   `PRM_STATE_FIL`: Filter State Parameter.
*   `ACTION_ERRM_Record`: A record of the error action.

## Logic Flow

### Filter Section (Top)

1.  **PWM Signal Difference Calculation:** The difference between `C_ABC_DEC_ETC_PWM` and `C_ABC_INC_ETC_PWM` is calculated. This difference is then limited by a saturation block checking if it is close to 0.
2.  **PWM Signal Adjustment:** This difference is subtracted from current PWM Value `[ABC_ETC_PWM]`.
3.  **Maximum PWM Limitation:** This value is then limited by `max` block which selects the maximum between result of step 2 and `ABC_ETC_PWMMin`.
4.  **State Logic (Lower Path):** `C_ABC_MAX_ETC_PWM_1` is checked to be greater than `ABC_ETC_PWMMin` using <= and > blocks. The output of both blocks are passed to an AND block, If the condition is true, `cond_if` (from V.6.4) signal is output. This goes to an `if` block which outputs `PASS` (= +1.00000e+000) when the condition is true and `NO_EVE` (= +0.00000e+000) when it is false. This signal `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_1` is then created using a merge block.
5.  **State Logic (Upper Path):** Similar to the lower path, `[ABC_ETC_PWM]` is checked to be equal and not equal to `ABC_ETC_PWMMin`. The output of both blocks are passed to an AND block, If the condition is true, `cond_if` (from V.6.4) signal is output. This goes to an `if` block which outputs `PASS` (= +1.00000e+000) when the condition is true and `NO_EVE` (= +0.00000e+000) when it is false. This signal `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_2` is then created using a merge block.

### Error Recording Section (Bottom)

1.  An action port (`if{}`) is triggered by `ACTION_ERRM_Record`.
2.  This trigger causes the `NC_IDX_ERR_ETC_PWM_1` and `STATE_FIL_ETC_PWM_1` values to be imported into a data store block (yellow block).
3.  The yellow block then outputs parameter values which are: `PRM_IDX_ERR`, `PRM_STATE_FIL`, and `ACTION_ERRM_Record`.

*   **LV_TPS_BOL_AD_ACT**: Throttle bottom of line adaptation active status.
*   **LV_TPS_BOL_AD_INH**: Global inhibit condition for throttle bottom of line adaptation.

## Logic Flow

The diagram represents a stateflow diagram, with transitions between different operational states.

1.  **Reset State:**
    *   The system starts in the Reset state.

        * VP_TPS_AD_EL_BOL_X = VP_TPS_
        * VP_TPS_BOL_OFS = T_TPS_BOL_OFS_INC = T_TPS_BOL_OFS_DEC = 0
    *   The system remains in the Reset state as long as the `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_INH` signal is TRUE (inhibiting adaptation).
    *   When `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_INH` becomes FALSE (adaptation enabled), the system transitions to the Wait state.

2.  **Wait State:**
    *   The system waits in this state until the adaptation conditions are met *and* `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_ACT` is TRUE.

*   When `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_INH` becomes FALSE (adaptation enabled), the system transitions to the Wait state.

2.  **Wait State:**
    *   The system waits in this state until the adaptation conditions are met *and* `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_ACT` is TRUE.
    *   While in this state, the system continuously evaluates the following condition:
        *   `LV_TPS_BOL_AD_ACT` must be TRUE
